item.title: GDC Festival of Gaming unveils featured speakers for new Luminaries Speaker Series
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

January 14, 2026

1 Min Read

Image via GDC Festival of Gaming

GDC Festival of Gaming has announced the featured speakers who'll be taking to the stage during its new Luminaries Speaker Series. 

A fresh addition for 2026, organizers are pitching the Luminaries Speaker Series as a three-day program geared towards "senior decision-makers" across the video game industry. 

"These big-picture, executive-level sessions will focus on the macro forces shaping the business of games and the future of the games industry: emerging platforms, transformative technologies, global shifts, cultural trends, IP ecosystems, and big-picture strategy," reads an announcement. 

Inaugural Luminaries include leaders from Google, Mattel, Nvidia, Bandai Namco Studios, Savvy Games, Lightspeed Venture Partners, and more. 

GDC Festival of Gaming attendees with a Game Changer pass will be able to access the Luminaries Speaker Series, which will run from March 10 to March 12 at the 500-seater Blue Shield of California Theatre at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts. 

You can find a select list of Luminaries Speaker Series sessions below. More will be announced in the coming weeks.

  • AI Trends and Futures: Ask Us Anything!

    • Bryan Catanzaro, VP Applied Deep Learning Research at NVIDIA

    • Alexandre Moufarek, Product Lead, Inception at Google DeepMind    

    • Julien Merceron, CTO of Bandai Namco Studios

  • Fireside Chat with Brian Ward, CEO of Savvy Games

    • Brian Ward, CEO of Savvy Games

  • The Attention Equation: How Gaming Wins Consumer Focus and What Comes Next

    • Kabir Ahuja, Senior Partner of McKinsey & Co.

    • Ichiro Otobe, Sr. Client Development Advisor of McKinsey & Co.

    • Itamar Benedy, CEO of Anzu.io

    • Moritz Baier-Lentz, Partner & Head of Gaming, Lightspeed Venture Partners

  • Other Notable Speakers Include:

    • John Spitzer, VP of Developer and Performance Technology at NVIDIA

    • Marcus Liassides, SVP, Global Head of Digital at Mattel

    • Bill Kleyman, Co-founder, CEO of Apolo.us

Related:Obituary: Groundbreaking Xbox marketer Albert Penello has passed away at 53

Game Developer and GDC Festival of Gaming are sibling companies under the Informa Festivals banner.

item.title: Report: Ubisoft laying off staff at Abu Dhabi studio
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

January 14, 2026

1 Min Read

Ubisoft has seemingly cut a number of roles at its studio in Abu Dhabi over the past month. 

The news comes shortly after the company confirmed the closure of Ubisoft Halifax and proposed layoffs at Massive Entertainment and Ubisoft Stockholm. 

According to multiple LinkedIn posts from Ubisoft employees based in Abu Dhabi—including one shared in the past 24 hours—it seems the French publisher quietly started the cuts in December 2025.

"Signing off as Ubisoft Abu Dhabi's Social Media Manager as I’ve been affected by the recent layoffs. I’m incredibly grateful for the 4 years and 9 months I’ve spent here," said one worker in a post uploaded to LinkedIn in December. 

"I took some time to reflect after being impacted by the recent layoffs at Ubisoft Abu Dhabi, and at the risk of sounding a bit sentimental, I just want to say how grateful I am for these three and a half years," reads another post uploaded at the same time. 

Yesterday, another Ubisoft Abu Dhabi employee who said they were impacted by "recent restructuring" explained their time at the studio is coming to an end. "It’s been a chapter full of learning, collaboration, and growth; I am incredibly grateful for the experiences, challenges, and people that made this chapter so meaningful," they added on LinkedIn. 

Related:Ubisoft to consider increasing compensation for laid off Halifax workers

Game Developer reached out to Ubisoft about the layoffs earlier this week. The company has yet to comment. 

Ubisoft Abu Dhabi was established in 2011 and is billed as a 'regional hub' for game development. The studio website notes the location employed over 60 people and has worked on titles such as CSI: Hidden Crimes and Growtopia.
